segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Jolanta M. Zurczak Pawlikowski, on January 21*, 2015, in Arlington Heights, Illinois. And thank you very much, Mrs. Pawlikowski, it’s been a long day. We’ve just had an interview with your husband, and I very much appreciate that you have allowed us, and decided to share part of your story with us as well. Thank you. So I'll start the way we did before. Please tell me what was your name at birth.
segments.answer: Jolanta Maria Zurczak.

segments.question: Zurezak. And where were you born?
segments.answer: I was born in Swieciechowa Powiat Leszno Wojewédztwo Poznanskie. That means I belonged to the Poznan territory.

segments.question: And what was the date of your birth?
segments.answer: August 23", 1938.

segments.question: Okay. So you were a baby when World War wa — World War II broke out?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. August 234, did you say?
segments.answer: Yes, ma’am.

segments.question: So you’re also — your birthday is the ma — is the date of the Molotov- Ribbentrop Pact. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection , Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Unfortunately.

segments.question: Yes. So tell me a little bit. Were you born in a village, in a town? Describe a little bit about the place where you were born.
segments.answer: My parents said I was born in a small town. They were teaching in surrounding areas of Swieciechowa and Leszno, and I lived there until the war broke out. So —

segments.question: Did you have brothers and sisters?
segments.answer: I have two brothers and a cousin, whom I call my first brother, because his mother, who is my aunt, my mother’s sister, died of tuberculosis in 19 — beginning of 1942. But I was raised with him. He is, I think, almost a year older than I am, and we were brought up together by my mother and my grandmother.

segments.question: Was — were your brothers older than you? Your —
segments.answer: No, I’m the oldest one.

segments.question: You’re the oldest one?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: One brother was born in 1940 in February, and the youngest one was born in July of 1946.

segments.question: Okay. Tell me a little bit about your parents. Who was your father, what was his name? The same for your mother. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: My father Jusef(ph) Henry Zurezak was a teacher. He became an administrator, a masters’ schoolteacher, and he was also a violinist.

segments.question: And your mother?
segments.answer: And my mother was a teacher majoring in mathematics and physics.

segments.question: Quite unusual for a woman.
segments.answer: Well, she had difficulties —

segments.question: Did she?
segments.answer: — with math when she started at, I think, the teachers’ sem — seminary in Leszno. And she got help. [indecipherable] f — from another teacher, someone who wanted to help her, saw that she was bright, but she was rather not too well. And it helped that she became one of the best students when she graduated five years later, so — and she loved math, so —

segments.question: That’s an inspiring —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — that’s an inspiring story, yeah. And when you — so if your parents were both teachers, were they very active in the community of students, and — and school activities, and — and things like that? Were they —
segments.answer: Yes, they were. Besides, both of my parents were scoutmasters. Actually, my mother was a scoutmaster of the youngest group, and she had only boys. But my fa — and my — my father became a—a scout when he returned to Poland in 1920 or ’22. I don’t remember —

segments.question: Did your father fight in the first World War?
segments.answer: No. Both of my parents were born outside of Poland. My father was born in Garnisonkirche, and then they moved to Dortmund, upper part of Germany, and my mother was born in Helma(ph) Wiesbaden —

segments.question: So their —
segments.answer: — the northwest part of Germany.

segments.question: Did you have German family, or German roots?
segments.answer: No, because during the partition of Poland, that part of Poland was part of Prussia. So they were taken — my grandparents were taken out of Poland to work, and my grandmother, my mother’s parents were taken to Wiesbaden because my grandfather was a forester and they needed someone to work there. And both he and my grand — my grandmother worked together. She took the administration under her hands, apparently that’s where my mother got these mathematical — 1-1t — influence. And my father took care of the — the forestry, the cutting and the taking care of and so forth.

segments.question: So they must have been bilingual.
segments.answer: Yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015

segments.question: They must have spoken German as well as Polish.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: Except that my grandfather, my maternal grandfather came from a family that, before the first World War, and I think it was at the middle of 19" century, they met — my [indecipherable] through Turkey from Macedonia, and through the — through the Carpathian mountains, came to Silesia, Shlunsk, and then — and — but my mo — my grandmother was from Vierkapolska(ph), the up [indecipherable] Poland. So somehow they — the families arranged it. He was dark, tall, my grandmother was blue eyed with very light blonde hair, and also tall. So —

segments.question: And on your father’s side of the family, how did — how did they end up, it was Garnisonkirchen(ph) —
segments.answer: Garnisonkirche, yes.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: My grandfather was a cobbler. He designed shoes and he was a very good cobbler because not only the Polish army, but later on the German army ordered the officers’ high boots to be —

segments.question: From him? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.answer: — from him. They brought the materials and two soldiers always watched the staircase, and sat there. He worked sometimes 12 - 20 hours, in order to finish.

segments.question: And this was during the second World War?
segments.answer: During the second World War, but during the first World War, he was in Garnisonkirche. He — I don’t know if he had interest, or he wanted to — not to abandon the — the — the Polish immigrants that were taken to — ba — by the Prussians to Germany. He received a permission to teach them religion. They gave him only the first part of the Bible, the Old Testament, written in old Polish. And for one hour on Sunday, he taught them the language, based on the Bible.

segments.question: Isn’t that interesting.
segments.answer: Ah, but also he worked in the underground, because he was working with the Polish workers, and they wanted to — they were fighting for their own rights, in order to receive proper payment, and to be properly treated.

segments.question: And this is in Garnisonkirche?
segments.answer: And this is in Garnisonkirche, but somehow I think somebody —

segments.question: Informed on him?
segments.answer: — informed on him, and he was told that the best part would be if he left — moved northwest, so he — they went to north Dortmund. And from there on he promised himself that he will not return to Poland until Poland had a government. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 The government was established in 1922, so I believe that it took them almost two years to travel back.

segments.question: Amazing.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: It’s not such a long distance.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: So clearly these are stories you must have heard growing up, from either your parents or your grandparents. Is that so?
segments.answer: Oh yes, Jaja(ph) would always t-tell me — my father’s father was also named Jusef(ph), and he would — I loved stories. Apparently I was the only girl at that time. I had 11 cousins, including my brothers and my cousin and I was the only girl in that age. I had cousins, girls, but they were older, much older than I was, about 10 - 12 years old. But —

segments.question: Well, that makes you quite special.
segments.answer: But I played with them, and when they were quarreling, they always said, okay, we have to have a general. Who is going to be the general? They pointed at me because I was the only girl. Would I quarrel with anybody”?

segments.question: Yeah. So, tell me a —a little bit about what happened to your family on September 1*, 1939, when Germany attacked Poland. You were a baby, so — This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski » January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Yes, I was a baby, but my mother told me. My father was in the army. He was already out of Poland, he was actually in the — on the border, Poland — Poland and Germany, past river Oder, because we lived between Warta and Oder. And my mother told me that September 1“, 1931, we became one of the first Reich — the Third Reich of Germany, the Germany —

segments.question: The [indecipherable] 1939.
segments.answer: — nine — yes, 1939, we became the Third Reich.

segments.question: So it was very quick, very quick.
segments.answer: Yes, because it was about 30 — 30 or 40 kilometers past Oder to the town of KoScian, that — it was not very far.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: They just walked in and marched to Poznan.

segments.question: And what happened to her and you and — what happened after that?
segments.answer: My mother — my father was in the army, called in August that he should come for to serve in the reserves, but then — well, he was a second lieutenant, being a teacher and a musician. So, he had the right to be called frontow(ph), right away.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And Mother tried to move closer to her mother, who lived in KoSscian, which was northwest of Poznan, and about 30 kilometers northwest of — of Leszno. And This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 4 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 we were right — few kilometers south. But she told me that she moved from town to town, zigzagging back and forth until she reached KoScian, because it was — she was already pregnant with my brother Andrew. But she reached KoScian and lived with my mother and her ailing sister.

segments.question: That is with your grandmother.
segments.answer: Yes, with my grandmother, mm-hm.

segments.question: And what happened with your father?
segments.answer: My father was caught in an ambush in — in the forest behind — around Oder, and that part of the regiment was practically annihilated. He was shot, was wounded. Those that were caught, which were about 10 — he said about 10, maybe 15 people, but no more, cause some of them were very wounded, but were alive. They took them, but he passed out apparently, and after two days, the German patrol was walking with dogs, and they stopped where he was lying, and the dogs know if somebody is gone or alive. And when they searched him they saw my father’s army registration ca-card, a teacher’s card, and that he was born in Germany, so they took him for one of his — one of their own.

segments.question: So he wasn’t —
segments.answer: They took him to Germany, they took him to a German hospital, and he, after a month, he came, he was well enough to speak, and he was interrogated. And my This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski " January 21, 2015 father said, I am not a German, I am a Pole. I was taken — I was born in Germany because my parents were taken there. This was during the part o — Prussian partition. So —

segments.question: And so what happened to —
segments.answer: — then he was — when he came through, they — because my father, being an officer, he was taken to Murnau, which is Bavaria, to a [indecipherable] camp. That camp was a camp that was dedicated or — or protected by Himmel(ph). And it was a camp to show off how the Germans treat Polish officers.

segments.question: So it was sort of like a show camp.
segments.answer: Yes. When there was no visitation, they would treat it like any other — well, somebody — a prisoner. And, I mean, they had to scrape food. My father liked to cook, and everybody knew this, so he sometimes actually — I said — he said, I talked at the wrong time and was sent back to the —

segments.question: The kitchen?
segments.answer: — kitchen, yes, the ki — the kitchen. And he said there, at least, I could s — I could scrape off the — the peeling — peeling the potatoes, I could as — I could scrape the — th-the peels and — and save it and then cook it behind the barrack, or underneath the bed, or — or so what — or whatever. So —

segments.question: So in other words, it was a show camp only sometimes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. segments.answer: Oh yes. They had an orchestra, he played in a co — a symphony. There was a theater, there were — they had lectures, because there were quite — many professors. Polish officers and intelligentsia were sent there. So — and he stayed there til the end of the war.

segments.question: Oh my.
segments.answer: When an American general was passing by, he opened — my father was right on guard at that time by the — by the gates. He opened, and he — that’s where my father learned some English, cause they wanted to show off that you could take English, you could take French, other — to improve yourself, to show off that you — that — that the Germans were treating them properly.

segments.question: And so that’s why he could practice his English
segments.answer: Yes, yes. And when he said, open the door, my father said, that was the first command of a different voice asking. I didn’t know what to do. But he said open the door, and he showed them what to do. So the other fellow who was with him, they opened the gates, and he went through, all around. And said, you, where 1s your family, do you have a family? And — and he said, my wife and children are in — in Nordhorn, in northern part — northeastern part of — of Germany, right next to the Holland border. So he said, I’m going to Munich, hop in. And one — as my father hopped into the sidecar of the motorcycle, he hurt his leg. By the time they This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 14 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 got to Munich, my father was collapsing. He had a cut on his right leg, and he already had poison. So they kept him there. But my father had a letter from my mother, who could write to my dad in Murnau only three times a — every year — every quarter, she could. Every four months she could write a letter. And she wrote to him that we are in Nordhorn.

segments.question: So that’s in the northwestern part of Germany, if it’s close to the Dutch border
segments.answer: Border, na — yes —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — northwestern part of Germany, right. Right.

segments.question: And — and so he’s liberated by an American general.
segments.answer: By an American general, yes.

segments.question: But —
segments.answer: And he left him there because the — because he — my dad needed —

segments.question: Medical attention.
segments.answer: — med-medical attention, and this was sometimes in beginning of May, and we didn’t see him til a month and a half later, when he came to Lingen(ph).

segments.question: So for all intents and purposes, your father was — survived the war, but he was out of the picture — This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski » January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: — as far as your life was concerned.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: You — did you remember anything of him in your first years, or is the first time you remember seeing him, is that month and a half later, when he shows up?
segments.answer: I didn’t — I knew only my father from the photograph that was standing on — on the the table, on the side table at home. And in-in-in the place where my grandmother lived, and when I saw him, as an almost seven year old child, I looked and I said, that is not my father. My father was a handsome man, with a bushy hair. This 1s a sick man, this 1s — cause when I saw him in Lingen(ph) in 1945 in July, I saw a man bent over, grayish hair and — and his face was grayish, it — he looked like he just came out of a tomb. He could barely walk, he was so weak. So, it was at — that’s the first time I heard him, after all these — after six years of not seeing him. Cause I was a year old when he left.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: When he was gone, and I did not see him before. But we, my mother and I, we stayed in — in KoScian. It’s through June of 1944.

segments.question: So you were there for five — five years.
segments.answer: Yes, yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: And your — and your first brother was then born —
Okay.
segments.answer: Yes. He was almost four years old when we were taken out.

segments.question: Okay. Was your — was your mother able to write to your father? Did she find out, did she know he was in this prisoner of war camp?
segments.answer: She found out through his — through his parents, who lived in the same city.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: My — yes —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — my — the Zurezak family lived KoScian.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And — and my father — my grandfather was the — was the shoemaker.

segments.question: Ah, so —
segments.answer: But — but what happened is that my mother was notified by her father-in-law where Jusef(ph) is and that she can only write once every four months to him. And so they — so that they, many times — my mother taught me that she would put her letter with their letter, in order to make certain that it gets there. So my father sa — had some letters when he came in 1944, when he appeared, because he kept This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. But certain letters, I’ve noticed that 1t was only my dear, or my beloved, and everything was blacked out.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Only he would — and [indecipherable] I’m kissing you [indecipherable]. That was all, because whatever he wrote in it, was apparently unacceptable. So somebo —all the letters were read through before they went to the — to the people, on both sides.

segments.question: Did he know that he had a son?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, and he knew —

segments.question: And so they let information through.
segments.answer: Yes, yes, that info — yes.

segments.question: Okay. And did you see much of your father’s parents, as in those first years?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Because we lived — he li — they lived behan — be — further from us, where the town square was, and a pond where beautiful white swans san — swam. And I enjoyed the swans. It was — I always ask my mother, please can I go to the market and buy — she says, but you’re only four years old. I said, Mama, I want to go and This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection is Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 see Grandpa, but I want to also see the swans. And I would always have a few crumbs of my bread left for them so I could —

segments.question: Feed them.
segments.answer: — and they would — yes, and feed them.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But we — we visited them quite often, as was allowed. We could not visit them during air raids, or when the soldiers were marching, practicing something like that, no.

segments.question: Was the town full of German soldiers?
segments.answer: Yes. We lived right across in a house, only in one room on the third floor — well, I mean, I — European would be second floor. But across the — the palace, which once belonged to my father’s great-grandfather.

segments.question: Oh wow.
segments.answer: And well, unfortunately, the SS cavalry occupied that. So — so we were very, very watched. And —

segments.question: You were watched because of that family connection?
segments.answer: That I don’t know. We were watched because my fa — my father being in Murdenau(ph), an officer, and they did not like my mother, who did not look very Polish. My mother was dark skinned, with pitch black hair and dark eyes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski " January 21, 2015 Slim. And she was petite, and they always called her — she had a name, of the black crow, they called her.

segments.question: The back cr — the black crow.
segments.answer: The black crow.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yes. And my mother, my brother and I were witnesses. Three times she was called. She rece — received a notice that she has to show up at the wall of the square where many executions took place, and th — the family, her family, that means my grandmother, my cousin and the two of us had to go and witness. And of course, most of the people were there too, witnessing who was being —

segments.question: Executed?
segments.answer: — executed. And they always left my mother til the end. My mother was al — and I remember her, she was always dressed in a black skirt, black shoes, black stockings, a white blouse, and she would walk in, and when they went to put the — close her eyes, put the band on her eyes, she says, I don’t need it. And then they would get ready, and the commander would come in and say, not today, black crow.

segments.question: So this was a mock execution of her? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 50 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Yes, yes. My — my mother was — when they, of course, was over, the commands were given, the SS left, the people were looking around, they said, oh, next time again. Next time again.

segments.question: And so you —
segments.answer: So three times, it was 1943, and 1944 was the last time. I think it was in — right after Easter, which was April.

segments.question: And you’re a five year old child?
segments.answer: I was five and a half. I was waiting — September wa — in ’44 was going to be my sixth birthday. I mean, not — not September, Au-August 23" was going to be my next birthday, when I would be six years old. But at the age of four, I knew how to read, how to count, and how to write. And when somebody says, how do you know what kind of a book is this, or what paper this 1s, I say, in Polish [speaks Polish] It had to rhyme, I don’t know why, because I — my mother always said, we’re going to Jaja(ph), or we’re going to Babcia for their birthday or their Imieniny, their name day. And Jola, you have to learn how to say another poem. So I had to learn this. And I said, why do you read to me? I know how to read. Babcia told me, this 1s this, this is that, and I — what does a child do when you cannot get out of the house because of the air raids? And even if we wanted to get This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. And watch out because when the alarm struck, everybody had to be inside.

segments.question: And there were lots of air raids?
segments.answer: Oh, rot — lots, lots. Especially — I remember those in ’43, and ’44, quite well.

segments.question: Well, you know, one of my questions is, what is your earliest memory. But your — whatever your earliest memories would be, they are during wartime.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Because, if you’re a baby when the war starts —
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: So, are your earliest memories connected to the war, or are they some —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yes, just — just to the war. I remember that the first memory that I have is when we were totally isolated from the bedroom of my cousins, from his mother, who was dying of tuberculosis. And in that room was a wind — veranda window, glass, that you — you know, there were shades that you could close and open. Why we were there, don’t ask me, I don’t know. Nobody ever told me this.

segments.question: Okay. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski ° January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Or maybe they told me, but I don’t remember. This was 1942, so I was barely four years old. And I was always afraid to go to that room, because there was — one wall was the glass, the opposite wall was composite of doors. And later on I found out that books were on one side, and a wardrobe was on the other side. But somebody took something out of it and left a black strip of a — I don’t know, maybe of a — a sash, or something, but 1t was looking at me. And when that black sash disappeared, I said she died.

segments.question: And were you right?
segments.answer: Yes. Because I told my mother this. And on that night, or day, she died. But I think — I don’t remember to be a child. I always had to take care of one boy, and the other on the other hand. My p — my brother Andrew was on the right side, and Izbisznik(ph) was on the left said. He was older, but he missed his mother.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I think boys are more babies in the — when they’re younger, they, I’m not sure a little bit later. Not all, but some do. But most of them do.

segments.question: But he was alone. He was alone.

segments.question: Underground.
segments.answer: Und — from the underground. And you know how women — my grandmother liked to go to church on Sunday. Wa — I never knew why, she only told me when she came to the United States in 1960, when my mother brought her to live here with us. She said, I always wore my — my original garb. Long skirt, with three underskirts, and I always had a shawl on my shoulders. And only — there were only a few pews in the front, and the rest was just benches, or people stood, or people sat on — on — well, on stones, or on little stools, or something like this. And my mother was not surprised that Grandma didn’t come after the evening prayers. But she didn’t come in after 10 o’clock. And then somebody knocked on the doors, and that I remember, because that must have been about 40 — end of ’44, or 40 f — or — or — no, not — yes, end of ’44 or beginning of ’45. And said, Manya, Babcia nie przyjdzie.

segments.question: What’s that mean?
segments.answer: Grandma will not come. Where is she? The Fara(ph) is closed. And only afterwards, when Grandpa — Grandma came to America in 1960, I asked her, I said, could you tell me what happened? You were always so avoiding — you were trying to avoid the — the issue. And we stayed together with my — I went to pick up the milk in the milk can from the gentleman that was delivering milk on the corner. I would pick that up, and I would go to the bakery with the 20 pfennigs or 10 pfennigs, whatever my mother left me, and feed th-the — the boys, and — and — and then we would stay inside, we would not go out. She says, you are to not leave the house. Do not open any doors, any windows. Stay in. And then grandmother came in. Apparently there was somebody. She told me. She says, he hid under our skirts. I was always praying that he would — whatever, the policeman didn’t stop me, didn’t tell me to get up. And he says, my legs were going like this, because what would I do? segments.answer: So-

segments.question: — understood the si — the story 1s, is that people were in church.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.answer: Yes. Everything —

segments.answer: Because they had to work. So —

segments.answer: Yes. Yes.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Yes. Grandma would have — read to us books. I did not see Polish books. She had Grimms’ stories, Anderson’s stories, children’s stories, all written in German, and she would read to us. Actually she was reading German, and talk — saying — reading it in Polish to us so we would understand. So my — my two brothers would understand what was going on. They said, why these funny names? But you know, it was — but — but I loved stories, I loved when she read, and then she would of course tell us. segments.question: Did you have any other friends, or was it a really closed world.
segments.answer: It was a closed world. So she was the only person that I saw. She didn’t come to our house, we always see — saw her in my grandparents’ house. But the only time I saw other children would — when we went to my grandmother’s — maternal grandmother — to Rattzot(ph), which was 70 kilometers away from KoScian, and this was going through a large forest. It was cobblestones, those were huge stones, the old — and when I — that — I always loved to go there.

segments.question: Must have been pretty.
segments.answer: Oh, not only this, it’s the smell of the forest, the — the vegetation. I-I could pick up the bluebells and — and during summertime pick up the blueberries and — and raspberries, because, you know, it was — this was an original forest, and I could pick up all the — all — oh, anything that I wanted, you know, of di — of — of vegetation. It — it was — I loved to do this. Of course, we were very tired by time we hit the village, but it was fun.

segments.question: And you — you were free from all of those constraints.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yeah. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: So tell me, when your father 1s liberated in southern Germany, in Bavaria, by the American general, he even knows that you and your mother and maybe your brothers too, are near the Dutch border. What happened that you get from KoSscian on the eastern side of Germany, to near the Dutch border on the western side of Germany, how did that happen?
segments.answer: Because on June sixth of 1944, at two o’clock in the morning, the Gestapo came and told my mother, you have one hour. Take only necessary things, and we will — and we will take you to the train depot in Koscian.

segments.question: And so that meant your mother, or all of you?
segments.answer: All of us. He didn’t say — he said all of us. And then we waited there, and waited. And in the morning, six o’clock, they told my grandmother that, you are not her family. What is your name? And my grandmother said, Meeshak(ph). And your daughter — my daughter is Zurezak. You can take Ratychuk(ph), your grandson, the younger grandson, and you can go home. She went home, she cooked a bottle of pea soup, and brought it 1n a can, and this was our only meal that we had until we reached outside of Poznan, where were put into a transit camp. segments.question: So — so it was you and your brother and your mother.
segments.answer: And — and my mother, right, right. And my mother was interrogated there for three days, who she was, why doesn’t she want to speak German. She says, I don’t speak German. But you were born in Germany, you had to learn German when you were in the seminary. She says, but I don’t speak German. She spoke — she actually spoke very poorly. She was very surprised that — as much as I could retain. And then after I became well, so I could — when I spoke, she opened her eyes, she says, Jola(ph), you speak German? Where did you learn this?

segments.question: Where did you learn it?
segments.answer: I said, I spoke it all the time, Grandma was reading in German. We had — you had to speak in German outside. Well —

segments.question: So Grandma —
segments.answer: — my grandparents spoke German. What do you do?

segments.question: So your grandmother read to you from the Grimms?’ fairy tales in both languages?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: In Polish and in German. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.answer: She ti — yes, she wou — she would read it and translate it. Actually, when I finally got hold of — when I was already eight years old, and I knew the grammar of German — but speaking is one thing —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — but knowing the grammar. And I said, I remember this, I remember this, I remem — oh. So she wasn’t reading in Polish, she was reading in German. But she knew it so —

segments.question: Well.
segments.answer: — well, that she could retell the story in the oth — 1n our language.

segments.question: In Poznan.
segments.answer: Ou-Outside of Poznan, yes.

segments.answer: We were there til October 10". We lived in barracks, like you would see barracks in Auschwitz, or wherever German camps were. segments.question: Volksdeutsche.
segments.answer: No, they were Germans.

segments.answer: Yes, yes, dry cleaning.

segments.answer: Because he was not well enough to be 1n the army, in the German army, because they were taken. He knew several languages. segments.question: Okay.

To a barrack where they were — we would — could take a shower. But my mother never allowed us to go alone. We were there only twice. Once when we came in and four months later. And on that day, in the morning, we were told to take our belongings and give all of ours clothing to be put through some kind of a disinfection, and we’re going to go to the barrack where everybody —can you imagine? All — all right, this was good thing. It was not very cold, but my brother was shaking, and he says, oh, woda, woda. He wanted waters, he wanted so badly to get a shower, or — or a tub or something. And my mother said no, we are going to stand in the longest corner, in the darkest corner of the barrack where the — the water is coming out. And you are not going to look at water. You are going to face your — she held our faces to her belly, and she would turn around when the water was coming out, because the water nas — was not only water. There was chlorine coming out, because it smelled awful. You cou — people were

segments.question: Choking.
segments.answer: — choking. And then it was hot water — I mean, there were people — I mean, this was decimation of people. We got out, thanks to our mother.

segments.question: So some didn’t make it out of there? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 14 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: I[—I—my mother said, I don’t think that half, at least half didn’t make it. Because the older people were left, and were put away into incinerators, because they had incinerators there. Because when I went, 35 laters to Auschwitz in ’79, my husband wanted to see Auschwitz. I went there, and I walked in, and when I saw behind glass, piles of hair, shoes, teeth, I just felt sick. And I walked out, and I started to cry. And I said never, never, it’s — everything came back. I was six years old again. And I was —

segments.question: Even though you weren’t in Auschwitz, even though this was in Poznan where this happened.
segments.answer: Yes. It —1t was in a transit camp.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But this came back, because we had the same things.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: And the pieces of that hard, squared bread, which was something wa — that was more than sawdust. But, you know, th-this — this I — I will never forget.

segments.question: You were such a child —
segments.answer: And for many, many years, I would not touch dark bread, square dartch — dark bread. I could not take it. I would rather turn around instead of, you know, explain or make a face. No, no, it’s not good for me, and I wouldn’t. Now I have to eat, This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection ‘5 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 because that’s part of my diet, but — and I got over it. But I will never go back to Auschwitz, never. Cause I don’t think I could face it.

segments.question: I can’t imagine. I can’t imagine.
segments.answer: I wa —I went to the holocaust museum last Saturday to see Karski exhibit, and I saw certain pictures and I just turned around and I said no, I — I cannot face it.

segments.question: You mean the one in Skokie?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: We were there several times. I went through the entire permanent exhibition of Auschwitz, Birkenau and — and Majdanek and others, pic — the pictures and — and artifacts that they had from those things. And I said no, I will not go there again. Not to that section. Bec —

segments.question: What happened after — I’m sorry —
segments.answer: Yes?

segments.question: You wanted to say something?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: What happened after you left the room with your mother and the chlorophyll and the water, and everything like that. What did they — This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection ‘ Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: We were shoved — we were shoved through a corridor where there were racks, hot racks, where our clothes that we could — if 1t were ours, or not, you had to take whatever was there, and my mother knew which —

segments.question: Sizes?
segments.answer: — this will — yes, this was fit you, this would fit Jandrek(ph), and you know, and so forth on. And we would put that clothes on, and we were — our bags were waiting already. I mean, what kind of bags. We had — I had the little valise like this, and another pair of shoes, which was outgrown already, because it was coming, you know, it was fall. And they put us on a train, on the last 100 wagon train from Poznan going —

segments.question: West.
segments.answer: — west. And when we came to the border of Nordhorn in Germany, there was a stop — or, no, it was not Germany — yes, we were in Germany, because Nordhorn was Germany, and then it crossed to Holland. And we got — th-the entire train stopped, my mother told me, and I remember this — this barking at — and she says, take — help Jandrusz(ph), because he’s ill, so that he doesn’t wet his pants. Okay, we took, and she said, play dead dog.

segments.question: Really? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection ” Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: [speaks Polish] And I know what that means, that means — there were many bushes on — there was a signal, and my mother told me, I apparently had scarlet fever at that time, so I had very high temperature. Because I don’t remember what happened, how I got, but eight days later I woke up in a beautiful white child bed in a hospital. And I looked around, and there was my brother laying in another bed, still in fever.

segments.question: So the last memory — memory you have is la — re — at this train station —
segments.answer: Yes th — in the bushes.

segments.question: — where it stops —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — and your — you leave the train, and there’s some bushes —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — and your mother says, play dead dog.
segments.answer: Yes. Play dead dog. And I don’t know where she went. I — I cannot see her. I only remember that my — not privilege, but my — I had to take care —

segments.question: Your duty.
segments.answer: My duty was to my brother, to take care of him.

segments.question: Okay. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 18 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Izbisznik(ph) was not with me, so I — I was always looking, where’s the other one? Because I was so used to it that there were two —

segments.question: Two.
segments.answer: — two with me. But no — and he was so weak, that he just fell, and that’s it. And only after two weeks, when I came really through, my mother told me that thank — I don’t know why I did this, but we are in a evangelical hospital, run by the evangelical nuns.

segments.question: In other words, the Lutherans.
segments.answer: Yes, but they were called — they were — this was a Swiss order.

segments.question: Evangelische?
segments.answer: Evangelische, yes, Lutheran, uh-huh, Evangelische schwester.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: They had navy blue garbs, white coifs with rows, and they all had beautiful, long hair. Some of them were very princely. There were baronesses, there was a — countesses, very wealthy women who did not want to marry this one or that one, would go to such an order.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: But they were this — they ran a hospital, because the hospital was right like on a peninsula. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: Okay. Well, how did you get from the bushes near the train station, to that hospital?
segments.answer: My mother told me, when I came through —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — and — and I will —

segments.question: Woke up.
segments.answer: Woke up, but when I could talk with her, she told me — I said, Mother, why am I — I never had a bed like this. Where — where are we? And she told me that in the evening a farmer was coming with hay and some turnips and — and potatoes. And she found her German language and ask him — he — she said, he spoke Plattdeutsch. He spoke, you know —

segments.question: Low German.
segments.answer: — low — low German, but he understood what she wanted. And she pointed to the two children laying there, and he told her he’s going to take her — us, to the hospital. And he took us there, my mother said it was two or three kilometers from that place, there was the hospital.

segments.question: My question is also, why did — how did the guards not see you? Where did the rest of the people go? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski " January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Timing. They had to — it had to be anybody who was sick, they would throw them out anyway, on one side or the other side of the train. On the same train was my mother — grandmo — godmother, with her two sons.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Who in Russolt(ph) had a hor — she was — she had many Arabian horses. She was training them —

segments.question: She had a horse farm.
segments.answer: Yes, she had a horse farm. And she was taken, her husband was taken, he was — he disappeared, I think he just was taken to a concentration camp, period. And they were very — they were quite wealthy, because they had a big estate, and all that stuff.

segments.question: To have a horse farm, you have to be —
segments.answer: Yes, and they — and they ha — and she and those two boys were on that train from some — probably from Poznan because that train was coming from Poznan stood from the ci — center of the city. Stopped there what — where the camp was, the transit camp, and we didn’t know this until later on, when m-my mother found out, because she wrote — right under, or before, or when they hit the border, there was a—a mine exploded, and many of the carts were turned over, people were This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection <1 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 killed. One of the boys died. Now, I don’t know if the older boys died — died, or the younger one, cause I never found out.

segments.question: So this was by the Dutch border.
segments.answer: Yes, by the Dutch border, right.

segments.question: Okay. And then the rest of the people, who were still prisoners, were taken someplace, is that correct?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: Were taken someplace.
segments.answer: Yes, they were taken to labor camps.

segments.question: And you — and your mother kind of got you off of the train?
segments.answer: Right, right.

segments.question: And — 1-in a moment when nobody was looking? Is this —
segments.answer: Everybody. Everybody was coming out, you see.

segments.question: Oh, I see.
segments.answer: Everybody was supposed to come out. This was yo-your — your last chance.

segments.question: Your last stop, or your last chance?
segments.answer: Well, our last chance before we go to the freedom. This is what we — my mother said later on, when we were talking about it. Sure, because the Germans were taking us out of the bombardment — bombardments and — This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection , Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015

segments.question: Into labor camps.
segments.answer: Yes. Yes, either to work on farms, or 1n factories, or wherever.

segments.question: An-And she knew your — your — you two were sick?
segments.answer: Yes, because she worked in the sanitary barrack —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — where they used — where — where they were disposing ointments, aspirin, and — and so forth on.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Medications of some kind.

segments.question: So it was a split moment.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: It was a split second sort of —
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: — how can we hide from this crowd of people.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay, now I get it. So you — now you wake up in the ca — in the hospital, and it’s a nice bed, and it’s warm and it — and did that mean freedom, real freedom?
segments.answer: I don’t — I didn’t know. I didn’t know where I was.

segments.question: Well, after she told you these things. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski ~ January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Well, she told me this many days later, because apparently, she said, I was so — I had such a fever that I was incommunicative for the eight days.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That I just lay there and she said they were putting me in — 1n cold tubs or something to, you know —

segments.question: Cool you down.
segments.answer: — to cool — to cool me down. And then they found out — I found out that I wanted to talk to my mother and I could not because I was stuck, I had — they didn’t know what it was. Apparently it was lockjaw. And then, after lockjaw, I got another measles, germ — the German measles, so I was locked up for another six months in a dark room. I could understand everything, but I could not communicate. I could show, I could write, but I could not speak.

segments.question: [inaudible]
segments.answer: And the doctor, who was — he was a Dutchman, Dr. Becker, who helped my mother — my mother worked 1n that hospital in a — a sewing room where they were repairing the bedsheets and sewing other necessary things and cleaning and ironing and so forth on. But she did not live in the hospital. She lived in a place that I found out only after Christmas, she lived under the stable. I said, what is under the stable? They had — the nuns had built a refuge for people who were This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection <4 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 running away, for soldiers, officers, people — Belgians, Yugoslavs, you name it. And there were over 200 beds underneath the stable built.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: Nobody knew, and nobody discovered, even though, besides the nuns, the Evangelische schwester, there were 30 brown schwester. Those were Hitlerjugend nurses. Not in white and blue stripes, but white and brown stripes. That’s why they were called the brown schwesters. And when the nuns ate, my brother and I, we ate with them, because one of the nuns, Sister Marta, decided that we were her nieces, and that we were in the hospital. My brother didn’t speak German, he didn’t even want to speak, period. He only talked to me — to my ear, when he wanted. But they took us, when we finished eating, they — the nuns left, and then the other sisters, the brown schwesters, the nurses came, and they sat in a different part of the — of the — what the ta — their tables was 1n a different —

segments.question: In the dining room.
segments.answer: —room in the dining room, right. And they had different dishes, because this was all provided by the —

segments.question: Hitlerjugend organization, mm-hm.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. We stayed there til Palm Sunday. On Palm Sunday, I couldn’t stand it, it was so loud. All the bells all of a sudden started to ring. I said, Mama, what is This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection - Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 going on? The Canadian Mountain Police regiment came first. The Canadian — the Canadians came in and — because Holland was already free.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: They marched, and all the bells in Nordhorn started to ring and then in — then the next and the next. And when my mother found this out, she went to Dr. Becker and she said, this is the end. She said, it’s not signed yet, but the war is over, because I received it from Munich, from the Americans, that the end — it’s the end of the war.

segments.question: On that Palm Sunday?
segments.answer: Yes, on that Palm Sunday. We were — I think we were the first ones to know about it, because it came from Holland. They just came across the bridge and went — came into Nordhorn, and that’s it.

segments.question: It’s in the — I —I’d have to look back on the calendar to find out when Palm Sunday was that year, whether it was early April, or later April, or —
segments.answer: You know, that I don’t know. My mother s — my mother said, I think it was in the middle of ’45 of April.

segments.question: So another three or four weeks and then it’s done. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 5 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: Yes. That’s right.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: And she found out a month — I think it took us another month, my mother found out that the General Machuk(ph) Cross, who was with the British Army, the — the division — artillery division was coming through from Belgium through Holland and into Germany and then crossing over. They — they stopped and — in Lingen, which was, I think, not far away from Nordhorn, and there a—a-—a camp that was a concentration camp for Russians, Yugoslavs, Ukrainians, Serbs and [indecipherable]

segments.question: Slavs.
segments.answer: All kinds of Slavs, because he was not only decimate only the Jews, but all the Slavs too —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — because they were — somehow they were together in — into — in this war. And my mother found out that there’s an organization from United Refugee association or organization, UNRRA.

segments.question: Oh yeah, UNRRA, mm-hm.
segments.answer: UNRRA. That they were trying to organize that camp for the other people that were on the German soil. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: So refugees, for — for refugees.
segments.answer: Yes, the refugees, yes. The deported people, right, DPs, as we were called.

segments.question: Yeah, DP, displaced persons.
segments.answer: Yes. We were really — well, we were displaced, but we were not displaced, we were — we were just transported. As an Australian 35 years later in America told me, he says, don’t you ever call yourself a DP. You are a delayed pilgrim. When somebody called oh, you must be — not long ago somebody had some kind of an interview of people, and somebody says, oh, she’s a newcomer. | said oh yes, thir — 65 years ago I came to this country. I’m only a delayed pilgrim. He said, and what is that? He took off the — the macro — microphone. I said, a delayed pilgrim means the pilgrim who came later than the first pilgrims. Like 500 years ago, 400 years ago later. But it was, you know, that was something —

segments.question: Amazing.
segments.answer: And then we stayed in the camp. My mother [indecipherable] the do — the doctor found a transport for us that we were taken to the camp. It was awful. It was awful. Dead bodies, children slaughtered. I mean, it was awful. I couldn’t — I just couldn’t. I just took my brother and I sat under a tree and I said — and I just started crying, and that’s it. I said, I don’t want to be here, I want to go back to the This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski * January 21, 2015 hospital. But of course, you know the army came in, cleared, and there were people who knew how to organize things, who had the —

segments.question: So that meant the — these were the last prisoners who didn’t make it, who were killed in that camp?
segments.answer: Right, right.

segments.question: And they even had children in there?
segments.answer: Yes. Oh yes. And children found — went in barracks and places where it’s unspeakable to — to say it.

segments.question: And you, as a seven year old sees all this.
segments.answer: Yes, that — that — you know, I — that’s why, when somebody’s tell me, how was your childhood, I never had a childhood. And I don’t think I’m the only one. There were many children who never had a childhood.

segments.question: Did that have effects later on in life?
segments.answer: I think so. My uncle always called me — he said, you know, you are a martyr. I said, why? You’re always — you’re always looking for something to do, you’re always helping somebody, you always want to do this. Everything has to be cleaned, every — because I had the — oh, I couldn’t stand dirt, or anything that was crawling and moving, because I saw it under my skin, the bedbugs and — and the lice, and everything else. It was awful. Of course my hair was completely shaven This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection <9 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015 when I was in the hospital because it was falling off anyway. And — but somehow, you know, we survived, because my mother signed a paper in December of 1944 in the hospital. Dr. Beck — Becker asked her and told her that because this was a non-Nazi hospital, they had to accept all wounded majors, captains, generals, etcetera, etcetera, the higher officers of Germans were there. And they were the first ones to receive — that hospital was the first one to receive penicillin. And he said, and in order for her to speak, the only thing that I know that could help her is ultraviolet ray infiltration. So they —

segments.question: For you to speak.
segments.answer: To — to — yes, to loosen up, to —

segments.question: The lockjaw.
segments.answer: Yes, the lockjaw. And it worked apparently, because it took three — three months.

segments.question: So what was the paper that she signed?
segments.answer: She had to sign agreeing, because —

segments.question: Agreeing what?
segments.answer: That she permits us to get penicillin, and get the ultraviolet rays. Because it was unknown if it’s going to cure —

segments.question: Or not. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski " January 21, 2015
segments.answer: — or not. My mother said, 1t’s a 50-50 chance. He says yes. You don’t know, and we don’t know, but can we try? And in the hospital we had a stamp here, and they eradicated.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, we were stamped.

segments.question: Did you have a number?
segments.answer: I— we — that — I remember one zero something, and six four, and I don’t know whatever. It was a longer number, but I don’t remember. I — I just — when, many times I would get up and say, why this number comes back to me? And my mother said, because it was a number that was given to you. And because I had to remember it when I went to the — to the platz at eight o’clock in the morning, and waited there with my brother. It was rain or shine, we had to be there.

segments.question: So this was daily?
segments.answer: Daily.

segments.question: So while you were in the transit camp outside Poznan —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — there was this — this system, this order —
segments.answer: Yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection «1 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015

segments.question: Not order in the sense of things are in order, but this rule that the appell, the — the — the calling and the confirming of the numbers of prisoners — which is usually what it is, but I don’t know whether they counted you or not.
segments.answer: That I don’t know, but there were people who were taken out of the camp, put on a train to — outside to work someplace, to factories, to farms, for —

segments.question: During this time?
segments.answer: During this time, yes, yes.

segments.question: During this eight — six or — yes.
segments.answer: Because — because when we would come back, we would see, oh this bunk 1s free, this one 1s all the things are taken out.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And it’s being disinfected, so that means something — something has — I asked my mother once, and she said, because those people left already. And those that didn’t make it were put aside, and — toward the incineration, that’s it. Tha-That was the only way to tak — to get rid of the bodies. But you know, I don’t like to go back through — I do not think — that’s why I was very hesitant to — to — because it — I know I’m not going to sleep tonight.

segments.question: I’m so sorry. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 2 Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski January 21, 2015
segments.answer: But that’s — you know, somebody asked me once also, when I was in — in Washington, and I said, why shou — why do you want this information? Why do you want to interrogate me? This is not interrogation, we want to see what happened. Because you — your papers — you do — you don’t have certain papers, you don’t have this. I said, because I don’t have anything. If you want to, why don’t you write to Germany? Or find out?

segments.question: Did your daughter ever ask you about this stuff?
segments.answer: I think she knows certain things because I said, ask Grandma. That means, ask my mother. I said, my mother will tell you certain things. But my mother was very — she w — she was not scrupulous, but she only said — only told her certain things and that’s it. In general, that’s it, because she says, I don’t want her sh — because my daughter 1s very sensitive. She knows that, you know, his mother lived to be 103, despite the fact that she — it was meant for her to live that long. But they were very, very close, as a— as a family. The only time that he was away, and not living with her, was the two years that he was in the United States Army.

segments.question: That is your husband and his mother.
segments.answer: Yes, yes. She lived here, with us. I actually married both of them, as I always said. Yes. And you know, it was — it was different. She, in her later life dwelled on it. It was part of her [indecipherable]. She wrote certain poems, are very, very This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Jolanta Pawlikowski " January 21, 2015 strong, very beautiful, very formative. And I told him, I said, you know, I found certain papers, going through some of the things. He still doesn’t want to go and see them.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: But, I said, you know, they’re very good poems. And he said well, you would know. Of course, I — I am not — I am not a literary major, but I— I was a —I recited poetry, not only of Polish, but of — in — in — in Italian, and in — in English, and — and I love poetry. And you know, certain poems, when I had to translate from French into English and then write about it, what it really meant.
